results.title: Boro's ballet: the making of an Australian ballet 1939-1961
results.creator_credit: Michelle Potter, Sally Jackson, Jean Wein, National Library of Australia and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: ‘Boro’s Ballet’ focuses on the life of Edouard Borovansky (1902-1959) and on his dream of establishing an Australian ballet company. Borovansky, a former dancer with the Paris-based Russian Ballet Company Ballet Russes, moved to Melbourne and established a ballet academy and the Borovansky Australian Ballet in 1939. In 1960 Peggy van Praagh, a former dancer and choreographer with the Royal Ballet of London, inherited the company from Borovansky. It was renamed the Australian Ballet Company in 1962. The documentary follows his early struggles to establish a school, and pays tribute to his outstanding dancers. It features rare footage of the company in rehearsal and on stage from the 1940s to 1959. This co-production between Screen Sound Australia (National Film and Sound Archive) and the National Library of Australia comprises rare professional and amateur footage and other materials and memorabilia from their collections.

results.title: Borneo's cathedral of trees
results.creator_credit: Richard Brock and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: David Attenborough goes in search of wildlife in the Borneo jungle, and finds the world’s largest flower; night creatures such as the tarsier, the slow loris, and the pangolin; and the nomadic Puran tribe who hunt for food using deadly blowpipes. Suitable for upper primary and secondary years 7-12.

results.title: Borneo
results.creator_credit: Colin Baker, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Cinegroup
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Travellers’ guide to the Orient”.
Borneo has long held a fascination for travellers because of the variety of its land forms and the multicultural communities of its population. The video explores the range of islands which make up Borneo, taking us through Sabah (the largest island) then onto Selingaan Island home of wild and beautiful turtles. In Sarawak we explore the fairy-tale palaces of the White Rajahs and take a trip down the Skrang River into the rainforests of Bako. This beautifully shot video is a stimulating introduction to the geography and people of Borneo.

results.title: Born yesterday
results.creator_credit: George Cukor, S. Sylvan Simon and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Classic Hollywood comedy starring Judy Holliday and William Holden. Judy’s riotous performance as Billy Dawn, the clever ‘dumb blonde’, won her the 1951 Academy Award. Billy, her shady boyfriend and all his thugs move to a Washington hotel to begin wheeling and dealing in the political scene. To get her out of his way, and make her a little more cultured, and dignified, Billy’s gangster boyfriend (Broderick Crawford) hires Holden to teach her. Hilarious scenes and famous lines dot this film which has remained unforgettably and indelibly in the minds of audiences the world over. Based on the stage play by Garson Kanin.

results.title: Born yesterday
results.creator_credit: Luis Mandoki, D Constantine Conte, Lester Berman, Touchwood Pacific Partners and Hollywood Pictures
results.brief_description: A remake of the Judy Holliday film from 1950, this version stars Melanie Griffiths in the title role as the gauche mistress of a shady businessman. Keen to enter politics, but reluctant to ditch his liability, he makes her over with the aid of the tutor Paul Verrall (Don Johnson, in the role originally played by William Holden). Billie gains more than just an education however - she falls in love, starts to value herself and begins to recognise the transgressions of her brutish lover. Based on the play by Garson Kanin.

results.title: Born to ride
results.creator_credit: Steve Westh, Catherine Marciniak, Stuart Menzies, Tony Wright and December Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Grey voyagers”.
Mechanic Doug Sunderland has been riding motorbikes for 60 years. At 75 years of age, he sets out on a journey to ride through India and Nepal, overcoming ill-health and a collision to celebrate the new Millennium and 2 million kilometres in the saddle. During his voyage, he recounts the 6 years he spent in an orphanage, suggesting it fueled his desire to seek nature and open spaces. Doug also visits Rumtek Monastery in Sikkim. Cinematography by Catherine Marciniak. Edited by Tony Stevens. Narrated by Anne Phelan.

results.title: Born to boats
results.brief_description: Depicts the British as a people born to boats. Shows designing, process of vuilding, and use of yachts, lifeboats, racing shells, and other small craft. Scenes include yacht-racing at Cowes, Uffa Fox designing new speed-boats including Donald Campbell in his turbo jet boat “Bluebird” with his record breaking run at 204 mph, and rowing on the Thames.

results.title: Born to be wild
results.creator_credit: John Gray, Jeffrey Silver, Robert Newmyer, Outlaw Productions and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Katie is a very special three year old gorilla who knows how to communicate using sign language and loves to talk to her friend, Rick (Will Horneff). Rick meets Katie through his mother, a behavioural scientist who is so busy working with animals that she doesn’t have time for her son who is sinking into juvenile delinquency. Their friendship is threatened when Katie is reclaimed by her former owner and put in a cage with the intention of being used as an attraction at the flea market. Rick helps Katie escape and together they embark on an exciting wilderness adventure from California to Canada and having a lot of fun along the way. Cast includes Wil Horneff, Helen Shaver, John C McGinley and Peter Boyle.

results.title: Born to be small
results.creator_credit: Derek Hart, Tony Snowdon and Associated Television
results.brief_description: Looks at what it is like to be a “little person”, stressing that it is in physical size only that such people differ from others.

results.title: Born spastic
results.creator_credit: Spastic Society and National Coal Board
results.brief_description: Unambiguously, the film explains cerebral palsy and shows various activities of handicapped people in England, including sheltered workshops and social clubs, like Joe’s Club, which caters not only for the handicapped, but their siblings as well. Both the handicapped and the people involved with them discuss some of the problems faced by the handicapped in England.
